definition:
If $f(x)$ is a polynomial with integer coefficients and $x_0$ and $h$
integers, then the congruence $$\begin{aligned}
f(x_0\!+\!h) \;\equiv\; f(x_0)+f'(x_0)h \;\; \pmod{h^2}\end{aligned}$$
is in force.

[*Proof.*]{} Because of the linear properties of (1) we can confine us
to the monomials $f(x) := x^n$. Then $f'(x) = nx^{n-1}$. By the binomial
theorem we have $$\begin{aligned}
(x_0\!+\!h)^n \;=\; x_0^n\!+\!nx_0^{n-1}h+h^2P(x_0)\end{aligned}$$ where
$P(x_0)$ is a polynomial in $x_0$ with integer coefficients. The
equality (2) may be written as the asserted congruence (1).
